Award.AwardTitle: US-Egypt Cooperative Research: Metal-Organic Frameworks for Nanocatalysis and Removal of Mercury-Containing Compounds from Wastewater and Gas Condensates
Award.AbstractNarration:
1002970
El-Shall

This project supports collaborative research by Dr. M. Samy El-Shall, Department of Chemistry at Virginia Commonwealth University, Tallahassee and Dr. Samy Faramawy, the Egyptian Petroleum Research Institute (EPRI) in Cairo, Egypt. They plan to study ?Metal-Organic Frameworks for Nanocatalysis and Removal of Mercury-Containing Compounds from Wastewater and Gas Condensates?.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research is based on the potential promise by metal organic frameworks (MOFs) to provide answers to some challenging problems. MOFs, hybrid organic-inorganic materials, are new emerging class of porous solid state materials where desired functionality can be included either prior to the assembly or after post synthetically. The PIs plan to explore the unique properties of MOFs for mercury removal from natural gas and waste water. The proposed compounds cover a variety of MOFs ranging from neutral to ionic. The study will permit better understanding of the MOF structure and the mercury sorption properties. There is a basic component to the research regarding the development of appropriate materials for the stated applications, including identifying suitable catalytically active nanoparticles that will enhance the effectiveness of the MOF and ZMOF planned for main use. The project will involve the synthesis of these materials using newly developed microwave irradiation techniques, along with their characterization and performance studies. By tailoring the properties of MOF's and ZMOF's, the scientists expect to achieve a better understanding of the factors that enhance mercury removal performance of these materials. The PIs plan to mentor the young scientists on their respective international teams. The team is well equipped to explore the sorption properties of the organic and inorganic mercury species in the selected MOFs.

Broader impacts: The primary broader impact is the prospect of improving environmental quality in both countries, but education and training of students are also important results. The project will contribute to further interactions between scientists in Egypt and the US. The success of the project will advance the field of MOFs and solid state materials in general. The results from this project will give insight regarding potential use of MOFs for mercury removal. The scientists from both countries will gain interdisciplinary research training that is marketable in both countries. This project is being supported under the US-Egypt Joint Fund Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established research collaboration between the Egyptian Petroleum Research Institute (EPRI) in Cairo, Egypt and Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, VA (USA) aimed at developing highly porous materials for the efficient removal of mercury species from petroleum condensate and aqueous dehydration wastes produced by petroleum production plants. 

Mercury and mercury-containing compounds are highly toxic, difficult to handle and control, and have a tendency for accumulation in living cells. In spite of extensive research efforts on the removal of mercury species from natural gas and waste water, there is a shortage of effort focused on the mercury problem associated with petroleum condensate. Through the work done in this project, methods were developed for the synthesis of highly porous materials that can efficiently adsorb toxic chemical contaminants such as mercury-containing compounds from solutions produced by petroleum and other industrial wastes. These solid materials, known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), contain empty voids that can trap harmful and toxic compounds in order to remove them from solutions.

It is expected that, by tailoring the properties of materials developed in this work, efficient removal of mercury species from the processes of the petroleum industry can be achieved. The project also developed several new catalysts for the efficient transformation of petroleum products into high value chemicals. The catalyst systems developed in this project may lead to the development of useful commercial products for applications in pharmaceutical and chemical industries.

The scientific results obtained from this project have been disseminated to the scientific communities in the areas of chemistry, petroleum, engineering and environmental science through the publication of seven papers and one book chapter in addition to several invited and contributed talks at national and international meetings in the USA and Egypt.

The project also had broad implications in the education and training of graduate students and junior scientists in the multi-disciplinary research areas of nanomaterials, catalysis and nanotechnology. The project resulted in developing new facilities at EPRI in Egypt for the synthesis of nanomaterials. These new facilities have great impact on enhancing the technical capabilities of the EPRI and in creating new opportunities for research and development.

Besides the potential for broad environmental, societal and technological impact of research in nanomaterials for the removal of mercury, this international collaboration resulted in building strong ties between American and Egyptian researchers that will help train the next generation of globally-engaged scientists.
